Ok, here's to hoping this saves someone a lot of time.  Just spent an hour and a half debugging this.  I you are ajaxing for passport's req.user data using fetch()  you need to  specify the credentials parameter e.g.
```
fetch('/user', { credentials : 'same-origin' }).then(...);
```

@chrisdziewa Just FYI (and in case it helps you with yours): I figured out what was going on with my recipe zipline.  It seems that if someone *already had* a 'recipes' item in their local storage, then *that* item was getting called up instead of *my* recipes item.  I changed the name of mine to something less common, and that will hopefully have fixed the problem.

## :point_right: [arithmetic operators  [wiki]](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/arithmetic-operators)
JavaScript provides the user with five arithmetic operators: `+`, `-`, `*`, `/` and `%`. The operators are for addition, subtraction, multiplication, division and remainder respectively.

### Addition
**Syntax**

`a + b`

**Usage**
```js
2 + 3          // returns 5
true + 2       // interprets true as 1 and returns 3
false + 5      // interprets false as 0 and returns 5
true + "bar"   // concatenates the boolean value and returns "truebar"
5 + "foo"      // concatenates the string and the number and returns "5foo"
"foo" + "bar"  // concatenates the strings and returns "foobar"
```

*Hint:* There is a handy [increment](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Arithmetic_Operators#Increment_()) operator that is a great shortcut when you're adding numbers by 1.

### Subtraction
:pencil: [read more about arithmetic operators on the FCC Wiki](https://github.com/freecodecamp/freecodecamp/wiki/arithmetic-operators)

Deploying to Heroku

1. 
`yo angular-fullstack:heroku`
2.
`cd dist && heroku addons:create mongolab`
as per:
https://github.com/DaftMonk/generator-angular-fullstack#heroku
3.
`npm install grunt-build-control --save-dev`
https://github.com/robwierzbowski/grunt-build-control
4.
create MongoLab database
https://mongolab.com/home
5.
`heroku config:set MONGOLAB_URI=(url from mongolab)`
6.
`heroku config:set NODE_ENV=production`
7.
`heroku config:set IP=0.0.0.0`
8.
`heroku config:set TWITTER_ID=(id)`
`heroku config:set TWITTER_SECRET=(secret)`
`heroku config:set DOMAIN=(heroku domain)`
9.
`grunt --force && grunt buildcontrol:heroku`

on mdn: Calling a generator function does not execute its body immediately; an iterator object for the function is returned instead. When the iterator's next() method is called, the generator function's body is executed until the first yield expression, which specifies the value to be returned from the iterator or, with yield*, delegates to another generator function. The next() method returns an object with a value property containing the yielded value and a done property which indicates whether the generator has yielded its last value.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/yield

so MDN says
The function* declaration (function keyword followed by an asterisk) defines a generator function, which returns a Generator object.
The yield keyword is used to pause and resume a generator function (function* or legacy generator function). and 
Returns the optional value passed to the generator's next() method to resume its execution.
so it appears it’s simply looping back to pre like a do while or for each loop

- Define a factory that gets your initial data
- Inject that factory as a dependency for the controller
- The controller passes the data to the view
- The view renders the data

@ug02fast You’re question above is a good indicator of why Angular is weird. $interval is a wrap around setInterval, but isntead of returning an id like setInterval it returns a promise. thanks @BerkeleyTrue , and can you share an example of  how you include one jsx file in another - NavBar/NavItem for example?

Yes. I structure by view.
```
|- app
  |-App.jsx
  |-index.js
  |-components/
    |- NavBar.jsx (A composite component that includes NavItem)
    |- NavItem.jsx
    |- Footer.jsx
  |-routes/ (each view in app)
    |-login/
      |-components/ (each component that combines to make or is used in the login view)
    |-Jobs/
      |-components/
      |-routes/ (if jobs has subroutes they go hear and repeat the file structure)
        |- newJob/
        |- admin
```

@jondcoleman Soundcloud is not slow :)
Basically:  Blame cell phone users, the cads.  They need faster CPUs and more bandwidth.
So anything that allows you to do Server side rendering actually results in a cleaner/faster page for the user

So, this is pretty interesting - it sounds like the real issue is that our fundamental assumptions about network speed are wrong when you go worldwide and your "snappy" client side app is not so snappy when you're on a 10 year old computer behind a really thin data pipe

### Does Angular use the jQuery library?
Yes, Angular can use jQuery if it's present in your app when the application is being bootstrapped. If jQuery is not present in your script path, Angular falls back to its own implementation of the subset of jQuery that we call jQLite.

Angular 1.3 only supports jQuery 2.1 or above. jQuery 1.7 and newer might work correctly with Angular but we don't guarantee that.

@jondcoleman I like to work from the bottom up, by that I mean addressing the server / model side of things and layering on top. I'll usually create a very simple view for testing functionality, but that's it.

The text highlighting is a bit harder to do -- especially in text editors. If you're using a robust IDE like Webstorm, it should be possible because it most likely tracks variables that have been defined. It's usually not possible within a text editor (that I've found), unless you're using a linter like ESLint. If you are, then you can update your exeception file to not bark at certain variables (like `angular`), but that's really just a work around.
my NPM JSON package will also be in the root?
@johnstonbl01 Thanks I'm following clementine's layout. So will my github repo basically include the root?

@Beltayn 
- Typically the `app` folder will hold backend code for the app. If you look at the way Clementine is setup, there's an `app` folder within the workspace root. I recommend going that route.
- `node_modules` should be in the root workspace / project directory where the `server.js` file is located. You'll want to make sure that `node_modules` are in your `.gitignore` file so that they don't get pushed to GitHub. People can install the Node modules on their own environment.
- Only install dependencies globally that require global installation. These are typically rare. I recommend installing locally.

`alias commandName='actualCommand -with -params'`

Here is mine:
```bash
#!/usr/bin/bash

alias cds='cd /c/wamp25/scoreboard'

doedit() { uedit32 "$@" & }

alias e=doedit

alias ls='ls -F --color --show-control-chars'
alias ll='ls -la'

alias ga='git add'
alias gaa='git add -A'
alias gp='git push'
alias gl='git log'
alias gs='git status'
alias gd='git diff'
alias gdc='git diff --cached'
alias gm='git commit -m'
alias gc='git commit '
alias gma='git commit -am'
alias gb='git branch'
alias go='git checkout'
alias gra='git remote add'
alias grr='git remote rm'
alias gpu='git pull'
alias gcl='git clone'
```
That'll create it if it's not there

As @hansinla pointed out, `process.cwd()` will take the directory from which you executed the `node` command, which in the case of Clementine is the root project directory. This allows some jumping around for folders (I'm not a huge fan of relative path strings). Additionally, keep in mind that there are some static paths defined in the `server.js` file that allow for shortcuts to a few paths. Hope that helps. ;)

@tomsun100 It can be pretty confusing, for sure.  The thing that I found very valuable was to open my Dev Tools and go to the network tab.  Anything you see THERE is a server side route and must be responded to by the server.  For example, if from angular you do a `$http.get` request, that has to go over the network, via an AJAX request.
@SaintPeter http://i.imgur.com/EucIfYY.gif

@tomsun100 Does that help?

@tomsun100 
**Angular/Client Side Routing**
Angular (and other client side frameworks) completely abstract routing, making it a proxy for deciding which screens/templates to show at a given time.  With HTML5 enabled browsers, these frameworks can even update the address bar of the website and simulate traditional navigation.  You can even use back/forward buttons on your browser to go through the "pages".

Client side routes can also have parameters which will automatically be parsed and made availibe to your scripts, on the client side.  However, there are no functional equivilents to the HTTP verbs.  Since everything is happening client side, there is no data trasnfer happening over the network.  In fact, once your page is loaded, typcally 
the ONLY transfers will be to send data to/from an API on the server.

@tomsun100 **Server Side **
Routes are the part of the URL that comes after the domain name but before any parameter.  IE:
`http://www.example.com/this/is/a/route/thisIsNot.html`
Historically routes were actual paths on the server that corasponded to actual locations on the server file system and pointed to actual files.
On modern systems like Rails or on Node/Express, or even Apache with `mod_rewrite` installed, a route is more like a RESTful descriptor of a logical location.  While you may still encode some path information in a route, as a practical matter it is entitrly decoupled from actual folders on the server.

You can set up routes to expect certain types of parameters which can be automatically parse server-side to do various actions.  Note that a route is not just the "path", but also the method used - GET/POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE - these are all HTTP methods.  The same path with a different method will call a different function.
EG:
GET /polls/:id might show a single poll
PUT /polls/:id might update a single poll (with POSTed data)

Ok I think I get all of that. I want to do client side rendering
@AdventureBear You can think of an API call as being a special case of serving a webpage.  Rather than a bunch of HTML or whatever being sent back, instead it's just JSON encoded data.

@AdventureBear ngView DOES pull information from the server - it pulls down the raw view/template/html file.  But the server is not modifying that file in any way - it just sends the bits over the network.  As opposed to pulling an .ejs file, which is rendered by the server before it is sent.
@AdventureBear When you're making an API call, you're sending a required from the client to the server to send "raw" JSON data back.  That data is indeed pulled from mongo.
@AdventureBear Doing everything clientside is generally more responsive, because you don't have to do a full page refresh - you can just pull down the data you need and modify the local page.

@AdventureBear When you're using ejs or jade, etc, you're "rendering" the pages on the server side.  They are basically creating an instance of the template defined by the ejs and it's being sent to the client (browser).  All of the angular stuff uses the client side as a starting point and then pulls individual templates off the server.  Those templates are then modified client side and data is pulled off the server via the API and also modified/displayed client side.

TheHippo if you could edit your answer to include what @Gloopy commented: "Angular's $http.jsonp converts the request querystring parameter from callback=JSON_CALLBACK to callback=angular.callbacks._0", so the response is not exactly JSON_CALLBACK() but angular.callbacks._0([ {"id":"1", "name":"John Doe"}, {"id":"2", "name":"Lorem ipsum"}]); If there is more than one request the second jsonp convert the request querystring callback=JSON_CALLBACK to angular.callbacks._1 and so forth, so in my case (PHP server) I am using $_GET['callback']to get the right callback name.' from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16344933/angularjs-jsonp-not-working

@emptyteacup I have it working on a local linux installation.  The free cloud9 server runs out of memory building the node_modules with npm install, and doesn't recover.  In the mean time, you can get going with version 2.1.1 of the generator by altering the install command as such:
```
rm -rf * && echo "export NODE_PATH=$NODE_PATH:/home/ubuntu/.nvm/v0.10.35/lib/node_modules" >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc && npm install -g yo grunt grunt-cli generator-angular-fullstack@2.1.1 && yo angular-fullstack
```

For posterity, you must run 'nvm install 0.12' first, then the waypoint command modified to reflect the current node version:
```
rm -rf * && echo "export NODE_PATH=$NODE_PATH:/home/ubuntu/.nvm/v0.12.7/lib/node_modules" >> ~/.bashrc && source ~/.bashrc && npm install -g yo grunt grunt-cli generator-angular-fullstack && yo angular-fullstack
```
A nice sudo apt-get update wouldn't hurt either.

I would also suggest to put attention to:
* **Different design patterns**: the design requirements (not only the design of the views but also the routing, etc) of a SPA are different when compared to classic websites. It is so important, that I have found a lot of material online discussing how to organise folders (eg. some SPA developers appear not being happy with the yeoman angular-fullstack structure...)
* **Authorization and Security**: yes, it is ok to say that this is a beginner course, but unfortunately security is one of the most important things to take in consideration when you are at work... additionally, the possibilities of using different authorization parameters (eg. token-based vs session-, cookie-, or other-based) are very affected for your decision of designing either a SPA or a full classic website.

@AdventureBear Re Directives vs Controllers: Disclaimer - still a youngin'.  OK, so here's how I understand it. Angular follows the MV* concept with its framework.  Multiple different things can bind the model to the view, it is not limited to just a controller for that purpose.  As its stands, we get fairly comfortable using the controller framework for the binding, and angular-fullstack is initially set up that way.  You end up with a DOM element like <div ng-controller="MainCtrl"> in the view, which links to the model through that controller.  Directives work somewhat differently, you could have <main-directive></main-directive> and describe it within the confines of the directive.  The obvious difference is less of the detail is present in the view, so you have cleaner HTML, but more info within your javascript files, and some subdirectory with HTML code that describes the directive markup.  The functionality of the directive is contained within the "link" element, although there are other ways to do it.  I am certain certain tasks favor the controller framework, while others favor a directive.  My primary point last night was we should be as familiar as possible with directives while we are learning.  I have resisted them a bit so far, and I think that is a mistake.  2016 is the year of Angular 2.0, be ready...

@smirciat I did figure out the client IP address.   The key is that I need to generate my `index.html` with a javascript global set with express.js's `req.ip` parameter.  In order to do that I needed to parse/generate my `index.html`on the server.  
By default the Yeoman router is set up to serve static pages to all routes, so that wasn't going to work.  Luckily the default Yeoman install includes the `ejs` templating engine.  It allows you to embed server side variables into html documents it serves.  I changed the setup in `/server/config/express.js` to change the render engine to `ejs`, setup a views path, and then moved my `index.hml` to a `index.ejs` in that path.  Then it was a simple matter to embed the javascript, which looked like this:
```
<script>
   var clientIP = '<%= clientIP %>'
</script>
```
The `<% %>` things are template markers for ejs.

@smirciat Great!! I went through the folders and files this morning (Europe). I made some annotations already. I will share my list with you, and maybe you can share yours with me, so we can decide how to split.

More than making a full text, my approach was more like listing some points to make it easy to read, for example:


-- Application Folder
-------------- Gruntfile.js
* grunt seems to control the configuration of the folders of the application
* it seems also the point of contact with yeoman
* grunt seems to play a role in the automation of the simultaneous  modifications of dependent scripts
* it also introduces and configures a daemon
* take care of some initial incompatibilities of standard configurations , like ngAnnotate and Uglify



I did something like above for every folder and file I found relevant.

I have some foundations about express, socket and now angular; as well as tried an authorisation setting before (password-local, session (which I am afraid is no ported with this generator...)), as well as some understanding of environment configuration. But far from be an expert, that is for sure !

From my previous experience one of the issues was that if you insert a new route as a separate file in express, for example, you have to modify several scripts before the new route can properly used. Although yeoman seems to take care of this, I don't know to what extent that would involve some limitations to the basejumps. And at the end it could be useful to understand how the files relate to each other and what is the enforced structure that yeoman imposes (not the only existing one as you may have noticed...) so you quickly get an idea about where to work (and where not...).

By working on a wiki together we can do a peer review and edit/correct our mistakes.

So, an example might be writing a new object to the database.  In Angular you take the object and pass it via a POST request to the server side API, which accepts that POST request, extracts the object data, and writes it to the DB
IE:  You're sending a request to your server (Node.js) from your client (Angular.js) to communicate between the two

I'll admit, until recently I couldn't even figure out what Angular WAS, let alone what it DID.  Even when I was learning it, I was scratching my head trying to figure out why anyone would use it.

In the last few years I discovered Laravel, an MVC/ORM for PHP.  It was as though the scales had been lifted from my eyes.  Although I had already started to practice logic/display seperation, using templating systems, etc, now I could do it as part of my workflow.  Yes, it was a bit opeque at first, but once I got familiar with the tools my productivity skyrocketed.

I started out in web stuff working with phpNuke, an open source CMS based around phpBB 2.0.  I had heard that PHP was horrid and phpNuke in particular was bad, but I didn't really "get it".  It took several years of maintaining the site . . and getting hacked . . to fully begin to realize how bad it was.  There was php and html freely intermingled . . . data was never sanatized before being written to the DB . . . it was, in retrospect, a mess.  Moreover, it was a nightmare to maintain.  Making a "display" change could end up breaking critical logic.  Adding logic could break the display.

In defense of Frameworks:  They do make things a lot easier.  They reduce the amount of code you have to write and make the code that you write easier to maintain.  They allow a greater seperation of logic and display.

as I've been reading, the original reason for using frameworks were for cross-browser compatibility (which isn't an issue anymore) and structure. It begs the question: instead of spending the overhead on learning the framework's concepts, why not learn how to structure code better?

Hi People: is this the right place to discuss frameworks? I have been studying MEAN before re-starting some basejumps (I couldn't make them work in my first try).

My idea is to learn **to build prototypes**, but with a full understanding of the **backend as focus**, not necessarily frontend. It is why I **won't try Meteor** for the time being. I would like though to choose **only one tool I could stick to** that give me:
--- Certain **flexibility in backend**
--- Still, **some pre-shipped tools for quick deployment**, so I don't have to build everything from scratch (very much as with Express...): for example: the authorization middleware
--- Not too many folders that I couldn't understand where things are; this means, no necessarily a enterprise-minded framework, rather more an **start-up-minded framework**
--- I am happy with an **agnostic ORM** (actually, I prefer that...)

For example: I tried **mean.js** (Conf/Conv): very cumbersome for a beginner with no previous training in web dev.

The number of framework possibilities are overwhelming. I have been investigating several options and have some questions for you:
--- Many on Internet are more after **Convention over Configuration** (Conv/Conf) than **Configuration over Convention** (Conf/Conv). What do you think?
--- Then, I found that for the first (Conv/Conf), **Sails.js** looks like a good option
--- **Hapi.js** seems to be a good substitute for Express in terms of Conv/Conf
--- **Locomotive** is a bit as Hapi

@Fridurmus I have hacked a technique for disabling livereload if you are interested.  Page refreshes go from ~30 sec to ~2-3 sec.  And by hacked I mean its probably not the right way to do it, but it works.  There are 2 instances of "livereload: true" in gruntfile.js, turn them both to false.  Also, in express.js, comment out the line that refers to livereload.  You should get useable results after these changes.

For example: if you have a social media app where, on your wall, you have a *User* who has many *Friends* who have many *Posts*, each of which has many *Comments* (with a *Commenter*) and *Likes* (with a *Liker*)? The user model shows up four times (*User*, *Friend*, *Commenter*, *Liker*), which means that you’ll end up with a ton of queries.

In a relational database, you’d join the tables and get all your data in one transaction. Is there something you can do in Mongo to make that more reasonable?

I have a question about mongo vs. relational databases. Mongo claims that it is much faster and more scalable than relational databases. Most database designs that I’ve used have interrelated data sets, and there’s a lot of table joining to prevent N+1 performance issues. Is there a way to achieve the same thing in Mongo, or is that just a tradeoff you need to make for its flexibility?

that views folder is only for server rendered views which there's only one; a 404 page for routes that cannot be found
all the client side views are under `client/app/`
where did your views go to?

so you could condense it to this
```
├── client
│   ├── app                 - All of our app specific components go in here
│   ├── assets              - Custom assets: fonts, images, etc…
│
└── server
    ├── api                 - Our apps server api
    ├── config              - Where we do the bulk of our apps configuration
    │   └── local.env.js    - Keep our environment variables out of source control
```

most of the work you do is under `/client/app/` for client side (angular) work
and server side is under `/server/api/`

I kinda got used to the generator and it organizes things something like this 
```
├── client
│   ├── app                 - All of our app specific components go in here
│   ├── assets              - Custom assets: fonts, images, etc…
│   ├── components          - Our reusable components, non-specific to to our app
│
├── e2e                     - Our protractor end to end tests
│
└── server
    ├── api                 - Our apps server api
    ├── auth                - For handling authentication with different auth strategies
    ├── components          - Our reusable or app-wide components
    ├── config              - Where we do the bulk of our apps configuration
    │   └── local.env.js    - Keep our environment variables out of source control
    │   └── environment     - Configuration specific to the node environment
    └── views               - Server rendered views
```

@AdventureBear Oh, there's always more...  That's why we're here!  I was hacking through an ng-repeat loop with references like $parent.attribute and getting infinite loop errors due to scoping when I stumbled on that technique.  It works very well, and is clean.  The best part is the inner controller is assigned to each iteration of the loop, so its easy to visualize what is going on.  According to the angular docs, this is the only situation where ng-init is appropriate, and its used to initialize values in the inner controller taken from the outer contoller.
@smirciat  you just blew my mind.  I thought I had controllers in hand, but apparently there's more. :) lol

@AkiraLaine @AdventureBear A nested ng-repeat might work very well for this.  Or for just an element, you could reference poll.options[0], but the length of the options array can change, so a nested loop seems like a better option.  Just keep in mind that an ng-repeat loop has its own scope, so if you need to do more than simply display the static data of theoptions elements, its a good idea to create and assign an "inner" angular controller for each loop.

Anyone wanting to reference previous discussions is welcome to check out https://gitter.im/SaintPeter/BangingOnYeoman

@leesharma Using the Yeoman framework, it is a bit overwhelming at first to try to pick out exactly how the Angular/Express interaction is carried out.  The good news is it just works and you just have to add and modify endpoints (like database tables) and routes (html views and accompanying scripts).  After doing this for a while and poking around, it becomes clear how it happens, but its not a simple thing to describe...  Yes there is a lot of repetition, but the generator handles a lot of that for you so you can focus on your model and implementation.

@QuincyLarson has asked the discussion at SaintPeter/BangingOnYeoman to slide over here.  We've had a lot of great discussion so far...
